metadata.title: Rigid Mini-Thoracoscopy Versus Semirigid Thoracoscopy in Undiagnosed Exudative Pleural Effusion: The MINT Randomized Controlled Trial

sections.abstract: Background: There is debate regarding the ideal instrument for medical thoracoscopy. The authors compared rigid mini-thoracoscopy with semirigid thoracoscopy for thoracoscopic pleural biopsy. Methods: Consecutive subjects with undiagnosed exudative pleural effusion were randomized (1:1 ratio) to mini-thoracoscopy or semirigid thoracoscopy groups. The primary objective was a comparison of the diagnostic yield of pleural biopsy. Key secondary outcomes were the comparison of sedative/analgesic dose, operator-rated and patient-rated pain on visual analog scale (VAS), operator-rated overall procedural satisfaction (VAS), pleural biopsy size, and complications between the groups. Results: Of the 88 screened subjects, 73 were randomized: 36 to mini-thoracoscopy and 37 to semirigid thoracoscopy. Diagnostic yield of pleural biopsy in the mini-thoracoscopy (69.4%) and semirigid thoracoscopy groups (81.1%) was similar on intention-to-treat analysis (P = 0.25). Although the operator-rated overall procedure satisfaction scores were similar between groups (P = 0.87), operator-rated pain [VAS (mean ± SD), 43.5 ± 16.7 vs. 31.7 ± 15.8; P < 0.001] and patient-rated pain (VAS, 41.9 ± 17.3 vs. 32.1 ± 16.5; P = 0.02) scores were greater in the mini-thoracoscopy group. Mean dose of fentanyl and midazolam received was similar between the 2 groups (P = 0.28 and 0.68, respectively). Biopsy size was larger in the mini-thoracoscopy group (16.1 ± 4.5 vs. 8.3 ± 2.9 mm; P < 0.001). Three minor complications occurred in the mini-thoracoscopy group and 6 in the semirigid thoracoscopy group (P = 0.11). There were no serious adverse events or procedure-related mortality. Conclusion: Diagnostic yield of rigid mini-thoracoscopy is not superior to semirigid thoracoscopy. Use of semirigid thoracoscope may provide greater patient comfort.
sections.methods: Investigator-initiated, prospective, randomized controlled trial at a single center (AIIMS, New Delhi) enrolling between July 2016 and June 2018. Adults with undiagnosed exudative pleural effusion, after non-diagnostic thoracentesis including cytology, were randomized 1:1 to rigid mini-thoracoscopy (Richard Wolf; 5.5-mm scope, 3.5-mm working channel; 3.5-mm rigid biopsy forceps) or semirigid thoracoscopy (Olympus LTF-160; 7.0-mm outer diameter, 2.8-mm working channel; flexible forceps) under moderate conscious sedation (midazolam and fentanyl). Entry trocars: 5.5-mm metallic for mini-thoracoscopy, 10-mm plastic for semirigid. Minimum biopsies: ≥4 (mini-thoracoscopy) and 6-8 (semirigid). Switching to the alternative instrument was allowed if difficulty obtaining biopsy occurred. Histopathology, mycobacterial cultures, and Xpert MTB/Rif were performed on all biopsies. Chest drain placed post-procedure. Follow-up to 6 months if biopsy was non-diagnostic.
sections.results: Seventy-three subjects were randomized (36 mini-thoracoscopy; 37 semirigid). Two crossed over from mini to semirigid for adhesions/maneuverability; in 2 subjects (one per group) the procedure was abandoned for limited pleural access. Baseline characteristics were similar. On thoracoscopic visualization, abnormal findings were present in 65/73 (89.0%). Intention-to-treat diagnostic yield was 69.4% for mini-thoracoscopy and 81.1% for semirigid (P = 0.25). As-treated diagnostic yield was 75.6% (mini) and 84.2% (semirigid) (P = 0.30). Adequate biopsies were obtained in all subjects in both groups. Overall, definitive histopathologic diagnosis (malignancy or TB) was achieved in 48/71 (67.6%): malignancy 37 (52.1%), TB 11 (18.2%), nonspecific pleuritis 21 (29.6%), and normal pleura 2 (2.8%). Biopsy size was larger with mini-thoracoscopy (16.1 ± 4.5 mm) than semirigid (8.3 ± 2.9 mm) (P < 0.001). Operator-rated pain (VAS) 43.5 ± 16.7 vs 31.7 ± 15.8 (P < 0.001) and patient-rated pain 41.9 ± 17.3 vs 32.1 ± 16.5 (P = 0.02) were higher with mini-thoracoscopy; overall procedural satisfaction similar (P = 0.87). Maneuverability favored semirigid (P = 0.003). Sedation doses (midazolam, fentanyl) were similar (P = 0.68 and 0.28). Minor complications occurred in 3 (mini) vs 6 (semirigid) (P = 0.11). No serious adverse events or procedure-related mortality.

population.text: Adults with undiagnosed exudative pleural effusion undergoing thoracoscopic pleural biopsy after non-diagnostic thoracentesis.
inclusion_criteria: Undiagnosed exudative pleural effusion after diagnostic thoracentesis including negative fluid cytology and ancillary tests
Adequate rib spaces for thoracoscopy on clinical exam
Pleural effusion amenable for thoracoscopy on preprocedural thoracic ultrasonography
exclusion_criteria: Unstable hemodynamic status (SBP > 180 mmHg, DBP > 100 mmHg, or SBP < 90 mmHg)
Myocardial infarction or unstable angina within preceding 6 weeks
Hypoxemia not correctable with low-flow oxygen (SpO2 < 90% despite 1-2 L/min oxygen)
Extensive rib crowding on clinical examination
Extensive adhesions and lack of pleural space on thoracic ultrasonography

intervention.details: Richard Wolf mini-thoracoscope (5.5-mm diameter, 3.5-mm working channel, 0° view) with 3.5-mm rigid biopsy forceps; 5.5-mm metallic trocar; moderate conscious sedation (midazolam 0.015 mg/kg and fentanyl 1.5 µg/kg initial doses, titrated); minimum 4 biopsies obtained.

comparison.details: Olympus LTF-160 semirigid thoracoscope (7.0-mm outer diameter, 2.8-mm working channel) with flexible 2.8-mm forceps; 10-mm plastic trocar; same sedation protocol; minimum 6-8 biopsies obtained due to smaller sample size.

retrieval.summary_tldr: In adults with undiagnosed exudative pleural effusion, rigid mini-thoracoscopy did not improve diagnostic yield versus semirigid thoracoscopy (69.4% vs 81.1%; P = 0.25) but caused higher operator- and patient-rated pain; biopsy samples were larger with mini-thoracoscopy.
retrieval.clinical_relevance: Semirigid thoracoscopy offers comparable diagnostic yield with better comfort; mini-thoracoscopy yields larger biopsies but with higher pain.
